description: Born on October 22, 1811, in Raiding, Hungary. Liszt's early years were spent in Raiding where he showed extraordinary musical talent from a young age.
Liszt spent a short period in Vienna as a child, receiving piano lessons from notable teachers such as Carl Czerny and Antonio Salieri.
Liszt moved to Paris with his family in 1823 and began his musical education under some of the finest teachers of the time, establishing himself as a prodigy.
Liszt spent time in Geneva giving concerts and further honing his virtuoso piano skills, gaining recognition as one of the greatest pianists of his time.
Liszt settled in Weimar in 1848, serving as the music director and conductor. He composed many of his well-known works during this period, solidifying his reputation as a composer and conductor.
In Rome, Liszt continued his career as a touring virtuoso and composer, weaving elements of religion into his works like the 'Christus' oratorio during this period.
Liszt spent his later years in Budapest, teaching, composing, and conducting. He made significant contributions to Hungarian music and culture during this time.
Liszt passed away on July 31, 1886, in Bayreuth, Germany. His legacy as a virtuoso pianist, composer, and conductor continues to influence classical music to this day.
